intro: Serrafalcus squarrosus var. minor, commonly known as the dwarf serrafalcus, is a rare and lesser-known plant species characterized by its compact growth habit and distinctive serrated foliage. It is native to specific regions with high humidity and well-drained soil, typically found in tropical or subtropical climates. The leaves are usually small, lance-shaped, and exhibit a unique waxy texture, while the plant produces delicate, clustered flowers in shades of white and pale yellow. Due to its limited distribution and specific ecological requirements, it is considered a challenging species to cultivate. Conservation efforts are ongoing to protect this rare botanical variant from habitat loss and over-collection.
